subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit 4 restructuring
msgSnippet: ... Agreed.  And since we re nitpicking, I also don t think the failure string should be the first parameter.  When I look at an assertion, I am more
messageBody:
On 10/31/05, Daryl Richter <daryl@...> wrote:
>
>
> > assertEquals("blue", sky.color());
> >
> > ...as, "assert blue the sky's color is".
> >
> > That's great for Yoda, but my human brain thinks
> > "assert that the color of the sky is blue" is more
> > natural. So, I'm often tempted to write...
> >
> > assertEquals(sky.color(), "blue");
> >
> > But that's wrong.
> >
>
> I'm with Todd. When I first started using JUnit it took me a while to
> get used to the "backwards" argument order.


Agreed. And since we're nitpicking, I also don't think the failure string
should be the first parameter. When I look at an assertion, I am more
interested in what is being tested than what will be displayed in the case
of a failure.

Spot the test:

assertEquals("The sky doesn't seem to be blue, please take a look outside
and confirm", sky.color(), "blue");

assertEquals(sky.color(), "blue",
"The sky doesn't seem to be blue, please take a look outside and
confirm");


--
Cédric


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
